awd_titl_txt: FW-HTF: Collaborative Research: The Next Mobile Office: Safe and Productive Work in Automated Vehicles
awd_abstract_narration:
The Future of Work at the Human-Technology Frontier (FW-HTF) is one of 10 new Big Ideas for Future Investment announced by NSF. The FW-HTF cross-directorate program aims to respond to the challenges and opportunities of the changing landscape of jobs and work by supporting convergent research. This award fulfills part of that aim, by examining whether and how a new technology can safely improve worker productivity, and well-being.
 
Current trends in the automobile industry make cars increasingly automated, allowing them to take on a growing number of driving tasks, while freeing the driver to engage in other activities. Millions of people spend nearly an hour of each work day commuting by car. Automated vehicles could allow part of the time currently spent driving to be used for work-related efforts. The goal of this project is to understand how current and future technologies might enable work to be done in automated vehicles. Reclaiming productive time from time currently taken up by driving could increase economic productivity, worker wellbeing, and firm profitability. The project focuses on understanding how technology can allow commuters to safely combine or switch between work and driving tasks. A new multi-interface in-vehicle environment for the support of work-related tasks, as well as safe driving, in automated vehicles will be developed and tested in driving simulators and real vehicles.  The innovative contributions to the in-vehicle use of speech and spoken interactions, augmented reality, and tangible user interfaces will have applicability to a broad range of settings, including for non-drivers and in mobile environments beyond the car. The project also includes activities to promote the participation of women in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics. 
 
Creating the systems that will allow drivers to safely engage in work-related activities in automated vehicles requires an interdisciplinary effort. This project will explore what types of work in automated vehicles can improve workers' job satisfaction and productivity, and the productivity and profitability of firms. Based on these findings, the team will create in-vehicle user interfaces that support work tasks, as well as safe transitions between engaging in work tasks and in driving.  Three types of user interfaces will be integrated: voice interfaces, augmented reality interfaces, and tangible interfaces. The team will also develop a probabilistic model to examine the ability of the in-vehicle interfaces to communicate to the driver the mode and limitations of the vehicle automation. The model will incorporate cases when the user transitions between the work task and the driving task. This will allow designing the interfaces such that they provide adequate support for the safe transition from the work task to the driving task, as well as an efficient transition back to the work task. The team will close the loop with design guidelines, by providing researchers, practitioners, and policy makers a broad set of guidelines, along with careful reasoning for their application in the design of human-machine interaction to support the work-related tasks of workers in automated vehicles.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our project explored how technology could better support people in evolving work environments, particularly as remote work became commonplace and automated vehicles emerged as potential mobile workspaces. Through careful research, we developed insights that can help shape technologies that enhance both productivity and well-being in these changing landscapes.

Intellectual Merit

Remote Meeting Effectiveness

We studied how distractions affected creativity and performance in virtual meetings. Our research showed that while multitasking participants contributed less time and fewer ideas than fully engaged participants, they could still make meaningful contributions. We also found that specific roles within meetings, such as note-taking, influenced how people participated. These insights can help organizations design better virtual meeting experiences that accommodate different engagement styles.

Digital Well-being Interventions for Remote Workers

During the COVID-19 pandemic, we conducted a long-term study on how virtual nature experiences and mindfulness practices affected remote workers. Brief daily exposure to digital nature scenes increased focus and reduced stress, while combining these with mindfulness exercises improved problem-solving abilities. Participant interviews revealed these simple digital interventions provided moments of relaxation and mental escape during workdays, addressing some of the challenges of prolonged remote work.

Designing Future Mobile Workspaces

As automated vehicles emerged as potential mobile offices, we developed detailed user profiles of different knowledge workers by analyzing occupational databases. This approach moved beyond general assumptions to identify the specific needs of varied professions. Using systematic design methods, we mapped out considerations for vehicle workspaces, including interface requirements, task types, and user comfort factors. Our machine learning analysis highlighted which occupations might benefit most from automated vehicle workspaces and what adaptations would be necessary.

Transforming Commute Time into Productive Time

We surveyed people about how they might use their time differently in fully automated vehicles compared to their current commutes. Respondents expressed significantly more positive attitudes toward working during commutes in automated vehicles than in current transportation modes. They anticipated shifting from passive activities like listening to music to more productive tasks like email management and planning. This research highlighted the potential for automated vehicles to convert previously "lost" commute time into valuable work or leisure time.

Integrating Work and Well-being

Through conversations with human-computer interaction experts, we explored how work environments could be designed to support both productivity and well-being. These discussions emphasized the importance of incorporating physical movement, varied communication methods, and opportunities for achievement in remote and mobile work settings. As automation increasingly shaped the workplace, designing technologies that complemented rather than replaced human capabilities became essential.

Broader Impacts

Shaping Future Work Technologies

Our findings provided concrete guidance for developing technologies that better support diverse users in remote and mobile work contexts. By understanding specific challenges like managing distractions and the benefits of well-being interventions, technology designers could create more effective tools that enhanced both productivity and user satisfaction.

Improving Remote Work Practices

Organizations and individuals could apply our research to develop better remote work strategies. Simple interventions like scheduled nature breaks or mindfulness moments could meaningfully improve focus and reduce stress, while understanding the dynamics of virtual meetings could lead to more inclusive and productive collaboration.

Educational Outreach

We developed programs to introduce high school students to the intersection of advanced vehicle technology and human-computer interaction. These initiatives aimed to inspire the next generation of researchers and engineers by demonstrating how user-centered design shaped emerging technologies.

Public Engagement

To share our findings broadly, we launched a podcast series on the future of work featuring expert conversations and research insights. This accessible format helped raise public awareness about the opportunities and challenges in our evolving work landscape.

By bridging research on technology, productivity, and well-being, our project contributed to creating work environments that better served human needs in an increasingly digital and mobile society.
